title: How to read more, faster and better - Quora

response.answer_text: I’d say it depends on what you’re reading and why you’re reading it. Is it to learn as much as possible? To feel accomplished by developing a reading habit? Either way, some general tips would be: Read books because you are actually interested in them, not because you feel obligated to by society. If a friend recommends a book to you, then by all means check it out. But if everyone says that you must read Charles Dickens for example, and you don’t care at all about him or the time period he writes about, don’t waste your time. If you’re going to be bored and force yourself through a book, then the only benefit of doing so is to tell people you’ve read it, which is frankly not worth the hours you may spend chugging through it. Focus on what you care about.As many will answer, which is true, the more you read, the faster reader you will become. You’ll start clunking words and phrases together quicker, and your overall speed will increase without diminishing your comprehension.Some people will tell you to take notes for comprehension. Personally I don’t go to this length, but I have no doubt it will aid in understanding the text better and especially remembering it longer after you’ve finished reading. If you want to really remember the books you read, talk about them with others. Join a book club, look at reviews on Goodreads and Youtube, etc. Immerse yourself in the community and compare what you learned to others.Finally, I’d say that it doesn’t matter how many books you read, but what you gain from reading. Again, if you’re reading books so you can tell others about how much you read, you’re wasting your time.

I know a lot of people are simply saying read at your own pace-which is a good answer- but if time really is a constraint, then there are some tips. 1: Know what you want out of the book before you start reading. Do some research, read the preface and find out what it is you are looking to get from that book. Once you’ve established that, you can skip over parts you don’t need and still fully comprehend the material 2: Read a lot, and think like the writer. This is a bit arbitrary, but when you are reading different books, your purpose in reading that book should be different. For example, if you are reading Hemingway, or Kafka, understand that the jewel isn’t the plot, but the writing themselves. 3. Utilize the internet, but not the way you think Internet is great for general summary and outline, but if you start reading hardcore books, you need more than the plot to fully understand what is going on. When I was a kid, I didn’t have the comprehension skills I have today, but was obssessed with Emerson. So what I did was, if i didnt understand a particular chapter, I looked up the summary online just for that chapter. This actually helps you in understanding the writing style of the author. Almost like decrypting, once you have an answer key to one chapter, you understand hwo the author uses words to arrive at his point.

It could be a newspaper, magazine, novel, poetry or a letter.Be clear about the purpose of reading the specific book. It is important because once you know the objective only then you will be interested in reading it.Avoid all the possible distractions before you set yourself to read.Clear your mind from external thoughts. Read every day (at least 15–20 min)Block subvocalization (good exercise - read any text and count in voice from 9 to 1, this one trains two hemispheres of brain and train blocking subvocalization while you reading, don’t worry about speed and comprehension, it’s just 5 min training for daily using)Train visual span (peripheral vision), read 2–3 words at one glanceTrain working memoryImprove vocabulary (you should recognize words fast)Play brain games (for example, Lumosity and Readlax, Readlax more for speed reading training, but Lumosity mostly for fun cognitive training. As far as reading faster, the answer is read more. Read constantly. The more you read, the more patterns you will discover. You will notice repetition and organizational elements. You will learn that you do not have to read every word in order to get meaning. You may even be able to read things in a different order and focus on what is important for you. This advice works for textbooks and nonfiction. This does not work for poetry and creative fiction. As far as reading better, the key word is focus. Why are you reading the book, novel, or passage? If by “better” you mean the most benefit for time spent reading, focus is a key. However, if by “better” you mean increased comprehension, which can mean an expanded vocabulary, the answer is the same as in my first line, read constantly. There is no other way to increase vocabulary. If this is your goal, try to avoid dictionaries as much as possible. Get the meaning of words in a sentence from the previous couple of sentences or the following few sentences. In other words, from context. Good writers fashion their writing so this is possible. You will find that you like reading in certain genres. My favorites are crime and horror. I force myself to occasionally read other genres such as YA and Sci-fi. Reading only favorite stuff will become boring and leads to decreased reading. Experiment with your reading choices. Look to Indie published authors for a great range in variety of genres and prices. There is a lot of free stuff offered daily.

Read whenever you get the chance, you have 5 minutes open up a book or your kindle and read a page or two, just keep doing it like that. Speed reading doesn’t necessarily mean reading comprehension, which is important to do. I can read very quickly, but I can’t quote you specific passages from books, while I can give you the entire summary outlined in full, it’s a trade off. Practice is really the only way you’ll get better at reading and accelerate your pace, there is no magical solution. When you read enough you’ll start flying over the words with your eyes and no longer say the words in your head as they’ll skip your language center completely and just turn into thoughts. When I read I don’t actually say the words in my head, I essentially play a movie in my head and the book becomes a film in my brain. I don’t concentrate on the specific words and so I don’t linger on them, my eyes are scanning them and turning them directly into thought. That’s why I’ll always read quicker than someone who reads every word and says it in their head, I’m processing information differently. Now on the flip side this makes it more difficult for me to read books that don’t have an entertaining narrative such as dry history books, text books, autobiographies that just list events and times that I can’t turn into a story. I could never read a math text book well because my brain processed the information differently.

Choose anything that you like to read and pick subjects that interest you. It doesn't matter if it's a magazine, newspaper, a blog, or a classic novel. If you pick something that interests you, you are more apt to pay attention to it, and you're reading will naturally become more fluent as you search for answers and connect to what you already know.

Just read books, I am a book lover and the best way to read more is to practice, practice and you guessed it, more practice. Like J.K Rowling said “if you don’t like to read, you haven’t found the right book.” Just find something to read that you are interested in.
You don’t need to make yourself read faster. Everyone has their own reading speed; not reading as quickly as others doesn’t mean you are less adept.
The simplest trick is to read with your finger tracing across the page; you can increase speed until you are running a finger down the page instead of across or under every word.

Now let me ask you how much you typically remember 3 months later. Chances are very little. Imagine how much more you will learn if you read a good summary and spend 30–45 minutes on it. You can really absorb so much more.
